Literature Review: Alan Turing's 1952 paper on reaction-diffusion (RD) systems laid the groundwork for understanding morphogenesis as a self-organized process emerging from physicochemical principles. Despite initial skepticism in developmental biology, RD models have proven remarkably effective in explaining vertebrate skin color patterning. This literature review explores the unreasonable effectiveness of RD in this context, highlighting its ability to capture complex biological phenomena without requiring detailed parameterization of lower-scale variables.Turing's original work proposed that spatial patterns could emerge from the interaction of two chemical substances with different diffusion rates. This concept, initially met with skepticism, has since been validated in various biological systems. Kondo and Miura (2010) demonstrated that RD mechanisms could explain the formation of periodic patterns in fish skin, providing strong evidence for Turing's theory in a biological context.One of the most striking aspects of RD models is their ability to recapitulate the diversity of actual skin patterns observed in nature. Manukyan et al. (2017) showed that a simple RD model could reproduce the complex patterns found on the ocellated lizard, including the transition from a juvenile labyrinth pattern to an adult spot pattern. This study highlighted the power of RD models to capture not only static patterns but also their dynamic evolution over time.The effectiveness of RD models in capturing the underlying dynamics of cellular interactions has been further demonstrated in studies of zebrafish pigmentation patterns. Nakamasu et al. (2009) used experimental manipulations and mathematical modeling to show that the interactions between different pigment cell types in zebrafish could be described by an RD system. This work provided a mechanistic explanation for how cellular-level interactions could give rise to macroscopic patterns.An important aspect of RD models is their ability to interact with tissue size and shape. Crampin et al. (2002) demonstrated that domain growth could have a significant impact on pattern formation in RD systems, providing insights into how organism growth might influence skin pattern development. This interaction between patterning and growth has been observed in various animal species, further supporting the relevance of RD models in biological contexts.The capacity of RD systems to generate ordered sequential patterning is another key feature that aligns with observed biological phenomena. Miyazawa et al. (2010) showed that the sequential appearance of stripes in the zebrafish mutant leopard could be explained by an RD model, demonstrating how complex temporal patterns can emerge from simple underlying mechanisms.Particularly intriguing is the ability of RD models to generate cellular automaton-like dynamics in certain reptiles. As mentioned earlier, Manukyan et al. (2017) demonstrated this in the ocellated lizard. Similarly, Allen et al. (2013) showed that the intricate scale patterns of snakes could be modeled using a cellular automaton approach, which can be viewed as a discrete analog of RD systems.Beyond recapitulating statistical features, RD models have shown a remarkable ability to predict actual patterns. Watanabe and Kondo (2015) used RD models to successfully predict the outcomes of experimental manipulations in zebrafish pigmentation patterns, demonstrating the predictive power of these models.The robustness of RD models to variations is another key aspect of their effectiveness. Barrio et al. (1999) showed that a wide range of patterns could be generated by varying parameters in a simple RD model, suggesting that small changes in underlying mechanisms could account for the diversity of patterns observed in nature.Finally, recent work has begun to bridge the gap between deterministic RD models and the underlying stochastic cellular processes. Woolley et al. (2011) demonstrated how deterministic RD patterns can emerge from stochastic cellular behaviors, providing a theoretical foundation for understanding how microscopic randomness can give rise to macroscopic order.In conclusion, the unreasonable effectiveness of RD models in explaining vertebrate skin color patterning is supported by a wealth of evidence. These models capture the diversity and dynamics of observed patterns, interact with tissue growth, generate sequential and cellular automaton-like patterns, make accurate predictions, and demonstrate robustness to variations. As our understanding of the molecular and cellular basis of pattern formation continues to grow, RD models are likely to remain a powerful tool for understanding and predicting biological pattern formation.
